db_utils¶

db_utils.check_consistency(crypto_id: str, start_date: str) → bool¶

сonsistency check for no spaces between timestamps

db_utils.create_combined_view(conn)¶

Create or replace the combined view for historical and forecast data.

db_utils.create_tables(conn)¶

Create tables historical_data и forecast_data, if there are none in database

db_utils.delete_view_and_tables(conn)¶

Delete the view ‘combined_data’ and the tables ‘historical_data’ and ‘forecast_data’ from the database.

db_utils.get_missing_hours(crypto_id: str, start_date, end_date) → list¶

Get a list of missing hourly timestamps for a given cryptocurrency within a date range.

db_utils.init_database_connection(**kwargs)¶

Initialize a database connection. Replaces DB_CONFIG from config.py by .env values. DB_CONFIG from config.py is usable, but .env preferred for security reasons.

Parameters:

kwargs – Database connection parameters (overrides defaults in DB_CONFIG).

Returns:

A psycopg2 connection object.

db_utils.load_to_db_forecast(dataframe, crypto_id, model_name, params, conn, created_at)¶

Save forecast data into the database table forecast_data.

The model name is dynamically generated from key parameters to avoid conflicts.

Parameters:

  • dataframe – Forecast data as pandas DataFrame with columns [‘date’, ‘price’].

  • crypto_id – The cryptocurrency identifier (e.g., ‘BTC’, ‘ETH’).

  • model_name – The base name of the model (e.g., ‘arima’, ‘ets’).

  • params – Dictionary containing model parameters, including ‘training_dataset_size’, ‘model_update_interval’, ‘forecast_dataset_size’, ‘forecast_frequency’, and ‘forecast_hours’.

  • conn – Active connection to the PostgreSQL database.

  • created_at – Timestamp representing the starting point of the forecast.

db_utils.load_to_db_historical(dataframe, crypto_id, conn)¶

save historical data into the database table historical_data with a ‘historical’ label

db_utils.load_to_db_train_and_historical(extended_df, crypto_id, conn, max_train_dataset_hours)¶

save both training and historical data into the database table historical_data.

the first max_train_dataset_hours rows are marked as ‘training’, and the remaining rows are marked as ‘historical’.

Parameters:

  • extended_df – pandas DataFrame with columns [‘date’, ‘price’] containing both training and historical data.

  • crypto_id – the cryptocurrency identifier (e.g., ‘BTC’, ‘ETH’).

  • conn – active connection to the PostgreSQL database.

  • max_train_dataset_hours – number of hours to be marked as ‘training’.

db_utils.load_to_db_training(dataframe, crypto_id, conn)¶

save training data into the database table historical_data with a ‘training’ label

forecrypt
